class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name"><a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/by/tanya-sichynsky" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Tanya Sichynsky</a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="css-3xqm5e" data-testid="onsite-timestamp"><time class="css-1g7pp1u e16638kd0" datetime="2023-08-03T13:20:02-04:00">Aug. 3, 2023</time></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To say, “I’m just going to make a sandwich,” can imply some level of defeat, of phoning it in, a sigh of acceptance. But a sandwich can be a litmus test for what you want to give on any one day.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">There are, of course, the low-effort sandwiches: the peanut butter and jelly, the classic grilled cheese, perhaps the avocado toast if you’re willing to stretch a definition. But then there are the exercises in true sandwich artistry, the ones packed with crunchy vegetable salads and tangy pickles and crispy tofu cutlets — sandwiches that needn’t be prefaced with “just.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A great vegetarian sandwich should be crunchy, creamy and a touch tangy, regardless of the energy you’re willing to expend. Below are four sandwiches that exist on various points of the effort spectrum, each of them tasty and easy to love.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Zero effort: A tomato sandwich</strong></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">You need little more than a <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/22/dining/you-dont-have-to-wait-for-peak-tomato.html" title="">juicy tomato</a>, white sandwich bread (preferably toasted for crunch) and mayonnaise to construct <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/19/magazine/tomato-sandwich-recipe.html" title="">this symbol of Southern summertime</a>. But don’t make just any tomato sandwich. Make Eric Kim’s <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1024442-furikake-tomato-sandwich" title="">furikake tomato sandwich</a>, which requires only one more ingredient but no more energy than the classic.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Furikake, the sweet-and-salty Japanese rice seasoning of nori and sesame seeds, helps the tomato reach its full naturally sweet and savory glory. Be mindful that some store-bought furikake contains bonito flakes, so read the ingredients before purchasing.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Minimal effort: A sort-of grilled cheese</strong></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Breaking out a skillet to sear your sandwich is about all Ali Slagle’s <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1024029-vegetarian-reuben-sandwich" title="">vegetarian Reuben</a> will ask of you. Part deli classic, part grilled cheese, her recipe plays up the most delicious parts of a Reuben: mounds of briny sauerkraut and slices of melty Swiss. It’s proof positive that even the most iconic meaty sandwiches can stand on their own without the meat.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Some effort: A curried chicken-salad-inspired hoagie</strong></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Cauliflower may not be able to do it all, but <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/06/dining/roasted-riced-cauliflower-recipes.html" title="">it can do most things</a>, including stand in for chicken in an apple, walnut and raisin-flecked curried salad. In his <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1024043-cauliflower-salad-sandwiches" title="">cauliflower salad sandwiches</a>, Ham El-Waylly roasts florets at high heat until they’re charred in spots and at an optimal soak-up-the-dressing texture.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Tuck the salad into split hoagie rolls and eat upon assembly, or wrap them in plastic wrap or foil to lug out to a picnic or the beach in a cooler. The sandwiches are even better after they’ve sat a bit.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Significant effort: A restaurant-caliber sandwich</strong></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Brooks Headley’s delectable <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1021237-superiority-burgers-crispy-fried-tofu-sandwich" title="">fried tofu sandwich</a> isn’t on the menu at the revamped <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/27/dining/restaurant-review-superiority-burger-east-village.html" title="">Superiority Burger</a>, so you’ll just have to make it at home to experience the shattering exterior of his once-beloved “<a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://ny.eater.com/2017/11/15/16657392/superiority-burger-tofu-sandwich-best-chicken" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">tofu-fried tofu.</a>” Alexa Weibel has thankfully adapted the recipe from the <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://wwnorton.com/books/superiority-burger-cookbook/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">chef’s cookbook</a>.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It takes some work, sure — you’ll marinate the tofu in spiced pickle brine for at least a few hours before twice-coating and frying it — but the results are enough to send you to the East Village in New York to revel in Brooks’s other exceptional creations in vegetarian sandwichery.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" I’ve since <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/04/dining/lets-play-recipe-matchmaker.html" title="">brought it back to The Veggie</a>, but it’s been a while since I put out a call for requests here.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">So let’s give it another go: Send your (brief, please!) request to <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/mailto:theveggie@nytimes.com" title="">theveggie@nytimes.com</a> with the subject line “Recipe Matchmaker,” and I’ll feature a few of them in next week’s newsletter.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Thanks for reading, and see you next week!</p><hr class="css-7ad88g e1mu4ftr0"/><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Email us at </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/mailto:theveggie@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">theveggie@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. class="css-1jihs6t e1mu4ftr0"/><ul><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">This streamlined version of the eggplant Parmesan skips the frying for <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/03/dining/eggplant-parmesan-recipe.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-dining&variant=show®ion=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">a recipe you’ll make over and over again</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">With minimalist branding and a higher price point, Diamond Crystal kosher salt <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20230807025813/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/01/dining/diamond-crystal-kosher-salt.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-dining&variant=show®ion=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc">is now chasing after “the aspiring home chef.”</a></p></li><li class="css-1rcz39t"><p class="css-ttf587 evys1bk0">Chilaquiles, fried corn tortillas covered in salsa, <a
